ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64

about.summary: The main janitor functions can: perfectly format data.frame column names; provide quick counts of variable combinations (i.e., frequency tables and crosstabs); and isolate duplicate records. Other janitor functions nicely format the tabulation results. These tabulate-and-report functions approximate popular features of SPSS and Microsoft Excel. This package follows the principles of the "tidyverse" and works well with the pipe function %>%. janitor was built with beginning-to-intermediate R users in mind and is optimized for user-friendliness. Advanced R users can already do everything covered here, but with janitor they can do it faster and save their thinking for the fun stuff.

The main janitor functions can: perfectly format data.frame column names; provide quick counts of variable combinations (i.e., frequency tables and crosstabs); and isolate duplicate records. Other janitor functions nicely format the tabulation results. These tabulate-and-report functions approximate popular features of SPSS and Microsoft Excel. This package follows the principles of the "tidyverse" and works well with the pipe function %>%. janitor was built with beginning-to-intermediate R users in mind and is optimized for user-friendliness. Advanced R users can already do everything covered here, but with janitor they can do it faster and save their thinking for the fun stuff.

name: r-janitor
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = "2.2.1" %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-janitor
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/janitor_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/janitor/janitor_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 27c401302a62cafe8e68e66a51073834bc7930872282e0feb151d13629ae6cdf

build:
  number: 1
  noarch: generic
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-dplyr >=1.0.0
    - r-hms
    - r-lifecycle
    - r-lubridate
    - r-magrittr
    - r-purrr
    - r-rlang
    - r-stringi
    - r-stringr
    - r-snakecase >=0.9.2
    - r-tidyselect >=1.0.0
    - r-tidyr >=0.7.0
  run:
    - r-base
    - r-dplyr >=1.0.0
    - r-hms
    - r-lifecycle
    - r-lubridate
    - r-magrittr
    - r-purrr
    - r-rlang
    - r-stringi
    - r-stringr
    - r-snakecase >=0.9.2
    - r-tidyselect >=1.0.0
    - r-tidyr >=0.7.0

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('janitor')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('janitor')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/sfirke/janitor
  license: MIT
  summary: 'The main janitor functions can: perfectly format data.frame column names; provide quick counts of variable combinations (i.e., frequency tables and crosstabs); and isolate duplicate records. Other janitor functions nicely format the tabulation results. These tabulate-and-report functions approximate popular features
    of SPSS and Microsoft Excel. This package follows the principles of the "tidyverse" and works well with the pipe function %>%. janitor was built with beginning-to-intermediate R users in mind and is optimized for user-friendliness. Advanced R users can already do everything covered here, but with janitor they can do
    it faster and save their thinking for the fun stuff.'
  license_family: MIT
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/MIT'
    - LICENSE

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

# Date/Publication: 2019-04-21 04:20:13 UTC
